medical: PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Microscopic hematuria. POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Microscopic hematuria with lateral lobe obstruction, mild. PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Flexible cystoscopy. COMPLICATIONS: None. CONDITION: Stable. PROCEDURE: The patient was placed in the supine position and sterilely prepped and draped in the usual fashion. After 2% lidocaine was instilled, the anterior urethra is normal. The prostatic urethra reveals mild lateral lobe obstruction. There are no bladder tumors noted. IMPRESSION: The patient has some mild benign prostatic hyperplasia. At this point in time, we will continue with conservative observation. PLAN: The patient will follow up as needed.
layman:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Tiny blood in the urine.  
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Tiny blood in the urine with a mild blockage in the side part of the prostate.  
PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Flexible cystoscopy (a camera is used to look inside the bladder and urethra).  
COMPLICATIONS: None.  
CONDITION: Stable.  

PROCEDURE: The patient lay on their back. The area was cleaned and covered in a sterile way. A local anesthetic (2% lidocaine) was put in the urethra. The front part of the urethra looked normal. The prostate part of the urethra showed a mild blockage in the side lobe. No bladder tumors were seen.  

IMPRESSION: The patient has mild, non‑cancerous enlargement of the prostate. For now, we will just watch and wait.  

PLAN: The patient will come back for follow‑up as needed.
